sentences: Knox CollegeGalesburg, Illinois12:13 P.M. CDTTHE PRESIDENT: Hello, Galesburg!
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: Well, it’s good to be home in Illinois!
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: It is good to be back.
label: true_

sentences: It’s good to be back.
label: true_

sentences: Thank you.
label: true_

sentences: Thank you so much, everybody.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: Thank you.
label: true_

sentences: Everybody, have a seat, have a seat.
label: true_

sentences: Well, it is good to be back.I want to, first of all, thank Knox College -- (applause) -- I want to thank Knox College and your president, Teresa Amott, for having me here today.
label: true_

sentences: Give Teresa a big round of applause.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: I want to thank your Congresswoman, Cheri Bustos, who’s here.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: We've got Governor Quinn here.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: I'm told we've got your Lieutenant Governor, Sheila Simon, is here.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: There she is.
label: true_

sentences: Attorney General Lisa Madigan is here.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )I see a bunch of my former colleagues, some folks who I haven't seen in years and I'm looking forward to saying hi to.
label: true_

sentences: One in particular I've got to mention, one of my favorites from the Illinois Senate -- John Sullivan is in the house.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: John was one of my earliest supporters when I was running for the U.S. Senate, and it came in really handy because he’s got, like, 10 brothers and sisters, and his wife has got 10 brothers and sisters -- (laughter) -- so they’ve got this entire precinct just in their family.
label: true_

sentences: (Laughter.)
label: true_

sentences: And they all look like John -- the brothers do -- so he doesn’t have to go to every event.
label: true_

sentences: He can just send one of his brothers out.
label: true_

sentences: (Laughter.)
label: true_

sentences: It is good to see him.Dick Durbin couldn’t make it today, but he sends his best.
label: true_

sentences: And we love Dick.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: He’s doing a great job.
label: true_

sentences: And we’ve got one of my favorite neighbors, the Senator from Missouri, Claire McCaskill, in the house, because we’re going to Missouri later this afternoon.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )And all of you are here, and it’s great to see you.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: And I hope everybody is having a wonderful summer.
label: true_

sentences: The weather is perfect.
label: true_

sentences: Whoever was in charge of that, good job.
label: true_

sentences: (Laughter.
label: true_

sentences: )So, eight years ago, I came here to deliver the commencement address for the class of 2005.
label: true_

sentences: Things were a little different back then.
label: true_

sentences: For example, I had no gray hair -- (laughter) -- or a motorcade.
label: true_

sentences: Didn’t even have a prompter.
label: true_

sentences: In fact, there was a problem in terms of printing out the speech because the printer didn’t work here and we had to drive it in from somewhere.
label: true_

sentences: (Laughter.)
label: true_

sentences: But it was my first big speech as your newest senator.And on the way here I was telling Cheri and Claire about how important this area was, one of the areas that I spent the most time in outside of Chicago, and how much it represented what’s best in America and folks who were willing to work hard and do right by their families.
label: true_

sentences: And I came here to talk about what a changing economy was doing to the middle class -- and what we, as a country, needed to do to give every American a chance to get ahead in the 21st century.See, I had just spent a year traveling the state and listening to your stories -- of proud Maytag workers losing their jobs when the plant moved down to Mexico.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: A lot of folks here remember that.
label: true_

sentences: Of teachers whose salaries weren’t keeping up with the rising cost of groceries.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: Of young people who had the drive and the energy, but not the money to afford a college education.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )So these were stories of families who had worked hard, believed in the American Dream, but they felt like the odds were increasingly stacked against them.
label: true_

sentences: And they were right.
label: true_

sentences: Things had changed.In the period after World War II, a growing middle class was the engine of our prosperity.
label: true_

sentences: Whether you owned a company, or swept its floors, or worked anywhere in between, this country offered you a basic bargain -- a sense that your hard work would be rewarded with fair wages and decent benefits, the chance to buy a home, to save for retirement, and most of all, a chance to hand down a better life for your kids.But over time, that engine began to stall -- and a lot of folks here saw it -- that bargain began to fray.
label: true_

sentences: Technology made some jobs obsolete.
label: true_

sentences: Global competition sent a lot of jobs overseas.
label: true_

sentences: It became harder for unions to fight for the middle class.
label: true_

sentences: Washington doled out bigger tax cuts to the very wealthy and smaller minimum wage increases for the working poor.And so what happened was that the link between higher productivity and people’s wages and salaries was broken.
label: true_

sentences: It used to be that, as companies did better, as profits went higher, workers also got a better deal.
label: true_

sentences: And that started changing.
label: true_

sentences: So the income of the top 1 percent nearly quadrupled from 1979 to 2007, but the typical family’s incomes barely budged.And towards the end of those three decades, a housing bubble, credit cards, a churning financial sector was keeping the economy artificially juiced up, so sometimes it papered over some of these long-term trends.
label: true_

sentences: But by the time I took office in 2009 as your President, we all know the bubble had burst, and it cost millions of Americans their jobs, and their homes, and their savings.
label: true_

sentences: And I know a lot of folks in this area were hurt pretty bad.
label: true_

sentences: And the decades-long erosion that had been taking place -- the erosion of middle-class security -- was suddenly laid bare for everybody to see.Now, today, five years after the start of that Great Recession, America has fought its way back.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: We fought our way back.
label: true_

sentences: Together, we saved the auto industry; took on a broken health care system.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: We invested in new American technologies to reverse our addiction to foreign oil.
label: true_

sentences: We doubled wind and solar power.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: Together, we put in place tough new rules on the big banks, and protections to crack down on the worst practices of mortgage lenders and credit card companies.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: We changed a tax code too skewed in favor of the wealthiest at the expense of working families -- so we changed that, and we locked in tax cuts for 98 percent of Americans, and we asked those at the top to pay a little bit more.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )So you add it all up, and over the past 40 months, our businesses have created 7.2 million new jobs.
label: true_

sentences: This year, we’re off to our strongest private sector job growth since 1999.And because we bet on this country, suddenly foreign companies are, too.
label: true_

sentences: Right now, more of Honda’s cars are made in America than anyplace else on Earth.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: Airbus, the European aircraft company, they’re building new planes in Alabama.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: And American companies like Ford are replacing outsourcing with insourcing -- they’re bringing jobs back home.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )We sell more products made in America to the rest of the world than ever before.
label: true_

sentences: We produce more natural gas than any country on Earth.
label: true_

sentences: We’re about to produce more of our own oil than we buy from abroad for the first time in nearly 20 years.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: The cost of health care is growing at its slowest rate in 50 years.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: And our deficits are falling at the fastest rate in 60 years.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )So thanks to the grit and resilience and determination of the American people -- of folks like you -- we’ve been able to clear away the rubble from the financial crisis.
label: true_

sentences: We started to lay a new foundation for stronger, more durable economic growth.
label: true_

sentences: And it's happening in our own personal lives as well, right?
label: true_

sentences: A lot of us tightened our belts, shed debt, maybe cut up a couple of credit cards, refocused on those things that really matter.As a country, we’ve recovered faster and gone further than most other advanced nations in the world.
label: true_

sentences: With new American revolutions in energy and technology and manufacturing and health care, we're actually poised to reverse the forces that battered the middle class for so long, and start building an economy where everyone who works hard can get ahead.But -- and here's the big “but” -- I’m here to tell you today that we're not there yet.
label: true_

sentences: We all know that.
label: true_

sentences: We're not there yet.
label: true_

sentences: We've got more work to do.
label: true_

sentences: Even though our businesses are creating new jobs and have broken record profits, nearly all the income gains of the past 10 years have continued to flow to the top 1 percent.
label: true_

sentences: The average CEO has gotten a raise of nearly 40 percent since 2009.
label: true_

sentences: The average American earns less than he or she did in 1999.
label: true_

sentences: And companies continue to hold back on hiring those who’ve been out of work for some time.Today, more students are earning their degree, but soaring costs saddle them with unsustainable debt.
label: true_

sentences: Health care costs are slowing down, but a lot of working families haven’t seen any of those savings yet.
label: true_

sentences: The stock market rebound helped a lot of families get back much of what they had lost in their 401(k)s, but millions of Americans still have no idea how they’re going to be able to retire.So in many ways, the trends that I spoke about here in 2005 -- eight years ago -- the trend of a winner-take-all economy where a few are doing better and better and better, while everybody else just treads water -- those trends have been made worse by the recession.
label: true_

sentences: And that's a problem.This growing inequality not just of result, inequality of opportunity -- this growing inequality is not just morally wrong, it’s bad economics.
label: true_

sentences: Because when middle-class families have less to spend, guess what, businesses have fewer consumers.
label: true_

sentences: When wealth concentrates at the very top, it can inflate unstable bubbles that threaten the economy.
label: true_

sentences: When the rungs on the ladder of opportunity grow farther and farther apart, it undermines the very essence of America -- that idea that if you work hard you can make it here.And that’s why reversing these trends has to be Washington’s highest priority.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: It has to be Washington's highest priority.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: It’s certainly my highest priority.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )Unfortunately, over the past couple of years, in particular, Washington hasn’t just ignored this problem; too often, Washington has made things worse.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )And I have to say that -- because I'm looking around the room -- I've got some friends here not just who are Democrats, I've got some friends here who are Republicans -- (applause) -- and I worked with in the state legislature and they did great work.
label: true_

sentences: But right now, what we’ve got in Washington, we've seen a sizable group of Republican lawmakers suggest that they wouldn’t vote to pay the very bills that Congress rang up.
label: true_

sentences: And that fiasco harmed a fragile recovery in 2011 and we can't afford to repeat that.Then, rather than reduce our deficits with a scalpel -- by cutting out programs we don’t need, fixing ones that we do need that maybe are in need of reform, making government more efficient -- instead of doing that, we've got folks who’ve insisted on leaving in place a meat cleaver called the sequester that's cost jobs.
label: true_

sentences: It's harmed growth.
label: true_

sentences: It's hurt our military.
label: true_

sentences: It's gutted investments in education and science and medical research.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )Almost every credible economist will tell you it's been a huge drag on this recovery.
label: true_

sentences: And it means that we're underinvesting in the things that this country needs to make it a magnet for good jobs.Then, over the last six months, this gridlock has gotten worse.
label: true_

sentences: I didn't think that was possible.
label: true_

sentences: (Laughter.)
label: true_

sentences: The good news is a growing number of Republican senators are looking to join their Democratic counterparts and try to get things done in the Senate.
label: true_

sentences: So that's good news.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: For example, they worked together on an immigration bill that economists say will boost our economy by more than a trillion dollars, strengthen border security, make the system work.But you've got a faction of Republicans in the House who won’t even give that bill a vote.
label: true_

sentences: And that same group gutted a farm bill that America’s farmers depend on, but also America's most vulnerable children depend on.AUDIENCE MEMBER: Booo --THE PRESIDENT: And if you ask some of these folks, some of these folks mostly in the House, about their economic agenda how it is that they'll strengthen the middle class, they’ll shift the topic to “out-of-control government spending” –- despite the fact that we've cut the deficit by nearly half as a share of the economy since I took office.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )Or they’ll talk about government assistance for the poor, despite the fact that they’ve already cut early education for vulnerable kids.
label: true_

sentences: They've already cut insurance for people who’ve lost their jobs through no fault of their own.
label: true_

sentences: Or they’ll bring up Obamacare -- this is tried and true -- despite the fact that our businesses have created nearly twice as many jobs in this recovery as businesses had at the same point in the last recovery when there was no Obamacare.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )AUDIENCE MEMBER: My daughter has insurance now!THE PRESIDENT: I appreciate that.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: That’s what this is about.
label: true_

sentences: That’s what this is about.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: That’s what we've been fighting for.But with this endless parade of distractions and political posturing and phony scandals, Washington has taken its eye off the ball.
label: true_

sentences: And I am here to say this needs to stop.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: This needs to stop.This moment does not require short-term thinking.
label: true_

sentences: It does not require having the same old stale debates.
label: true_

sentences: Our focus has to be on the basic economic issues that matter most to you, the people we represent.
label: true_

sentences: That’s what we have to spend our time on and our energy on and our focus on.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )And as Washington prepares to enter another budget debate, the stakes for our middle class and everybody who is fighting to get into the middle class could not be higher.
label: true_

sentences: The countries that are passive in the face of a global economy, those countries will lose the competition for good jobs.
label: true_

sentences: They will lose the competition for high living standards.
label: true_

sentences: That’s why America has to make the investments necessary to promote long-term growth and shared prosperity -- rebuilding our manufacturing base, educating our workforce, upgrading our transportation systems, upgrading our information networks.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: That’s what we need to be talking about.
label: true_

sentences: That’s what Washington needs to be focused on.And that’s why, over the next several weeks, in towns across this country, I will be engaging the American people in this debate.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: I'll lay out my ideas for how we build on the cornerstones of what it means to be middle class in America, and what it takes to work your way into the middle class in America: Job security, with good wages and durable industries.
label: true_

sentences: A good education.
label: true_

sentences: A home to call your own.
label: true_

sentences: Affordable health care when you get sick.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: A secure retirement even if you’re not rich.
label: true_

sentences: Reducing poverty.
label: true_

sentences: Reducing inequality.
label: true_

sentences: Growing opportunity.
label: true_

sentences: That’s what we need.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: That’s what we need.
label: true_

sentences: That’s what we need right now.
label: true_

sentences: That’s what we need to be focused on.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )Now, some of these ideas I’ve talked about before.
label: true_

sentences: Some of the ideas I offer will be new.
label: true_

sentences: Some will require Congress.
label: true_

sentences: Some I will pursue on my own.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: Some ideas will benefit folks right away.
label: true_

sentences: Some will take years to fully implement.
label: true_

sentences: But the key is to break through the tendency in Washington to just bounce from crisis to crisis.
label: true_

sentences: What we need is not a three-month plan, or even a three-year plan; we need a long-term American strategy, based on steady, persistent effort, to reverse the forces that have conspired against the middle class for decades.
label: true_

sentences: That has to be our project.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )Now, of course, we’ll keep pressing on other key priorities.
label: true_

sentences: I want to get this immigration bill done.
label: true_

sentences: We still need to work on reducing gun violence.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: We’ve got to continue to end the war in Afghanistan, rebalance our fight against al Qaeda.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: We need to combat climate change.
label: true_

sentences: We’ve got to standing up for civil rights.
label: true_

sentences: We’ve got to stand up for women’s rights.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )So all those issues are important, and we’ll be fighting on every one of those issues.
label: true_

sentences: But if we don’t have a growing, thriving middle class then we won’t have the resources to solve a lot of these problems.
label: true_

sentences: We won’t have the resolve, the optimism, the sense of unity that we need to solve many of these other issues.Now, in this effort, I will look to work with Republicans as well as Democrats wherever I can.
label: true_

sentences: And I sincerely believe that there are members of both parties who understand this moment, understand what’s at stake, and I will welcome ideas from anybody across the political spectrum.
label: true_

sentences: But I will not allow gridlock, or inaction, or willful indifference to get in our way.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )That means whatever executive authority I have to help the middle class, I’ll use it.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: Where I can’t act on my own and Congress isn’t cooperating, I’ll pick up the phone -- I’ll call CEOs; I’ll call philanthropists; I’ll call college presidents; I’ll call labor leaders.
label: true_

sentences: I’ll call anybody who can help -- and enlist them in our efforts.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )Because the choices that we, the people, make right now will determine whether or not every American has a fighting chance in the 21st century.
label: true_

sentences: And it will lay the foundation for our children’s future, our grandchildren’s future, for all Americans.So let me give you a quick preview of what I’ll be fighting for and why.
label: true_

sentences: The first cornerstone of a strong, growing middle class has to be, as I said before, an economy that generates more good jobs in durable, growing industries.
label: true_

sentences: That's how this area was built.
label: true_

sentences: That's how America prospered.
label: true_

sentences: Because anybody who was willing to work, they could go out there and they could find themselves a job, and they could build a life for themselves and their family.Now, over the past four years, for the first time since the 1990s, the number of American manufacturing jobs has actually gone up instead of down.
label: true_

sentences: That's the good news.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: But we can do more.
label: true_

sentences: So I’m going to push new initiatives to help more manufacturers bring more jobs back to the United States.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: We’re going to continue to focus on strategies to make sure our tax code rewards companies that are not shipping jobs overseas, but creating jobs right here in the United States of America.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )We want to make sure that -- we’re going to create strategies to make sure that good jobs in wind and solar and natural gas that are lowering costs and, at the same time, reducing dangerous carbon pollution happen right here in the United States.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )And something that Cheri and I were talking about on the way over here -- I’m going to be pushing to open more manufacturing innovation institutes that turn regions left behind by global competition into global centers of cutting-edge jobs.
label: true_

sentences: So let’s tell the world that America is open for business.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: I know there’s an old site right here in Galesburg, over on Monmouth Boulevard -- let’s put some folks to work.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )Tomorrow, I’ll also visit the Port of Jacksonville, Florida to offer new ideas for doing what America has always done best, which is building things.
label: true_

sentences: Pat and I were talking before I came -- backstage -- Pat Quinn -- he was talking about how I came over the Don Moffitt Bridge.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: But we’ve got work to do all across the country.
label: true_

sentences: We’ve got ports that aren’t ready for the new supertankers that are going to begin passing through the new Panama Canal in two years’ time.
label: true_

sentences: If we don’t get that done, those tankers are going to go someplace else.
label: true_

sentences: We’ve got more than 100,000 bridges that are old enough to qualify for Medicare.
label: true_

sentences: (Laughter and applause.
label: true_

sentences: )Businesses depend on our transportation systems, on our power grids, on our communications networks.
label: true_

sentences: And rebuilding them creates good-paying jobs right now that can’t be outsourced.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )And by the way, this isn’t a Democratic idea.
label: true_

sentences: Republicans built a lot of stuff.
label: true_

sentences: This is the Land of Lincoln.
label: true_

sentences: Lincoln was all about building stuff -- first Republican President.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: And yet, as a share of our economy, we invest less in our infrastructure than we did two decades ago.
label: true_

sentences: And that’s inefficient at a time when it’s as cheap as it’s been since the 1950s to build things.
label: true_

sentences: It’s inexcusable at a time when so many of the workers who build stuff for a living are sitting at home waiting for a call.The longer we put this off, the more expensive it will be and the less competitive we will be.
label: true_

sentences: Businesses of tomorrow will not locate near old roads and outdated ports.
label: true_

sentences: They’ll relocate to places with high-speed Internet, and high-tech schools, and systems that move air and auto traffic faster, and not to mention will get parents home quicker from work because we’ll be eliminating some of these traffic jams.
label: true_

sentences: And we can watch all of that happen in other countries, and start falling behind, or we can choose to make it happen right here, in the United States.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )In an age when jobs know no borders, companies are also going to seek out the countries that boast the most talented citizens, and they’ll reward folks who have the skills and the talents they need -- they’ll reward those folks with good pay.The days when the wages for a worker with a high school degree could keep pace with the earnings of somebody who got some sort of higher education -- those days are over.
label: true_

sentences: Everybody here knows that.
label: true_

sentences: There are a whole bunch of folks here whose dads or grandpas worked at a plant, didn’t need a high school education.
label: true_

sentences: You could just go there.
label: true_

sentences: If you were willing to work hard, you might be able to get two jobs.
label: true_

sentences: And you could support your family, have a vacation, own your home.
label: true_

sentences: But technology and global competition, they’re not going away.
label: true_

sentences: Those old days aren’t coming back.So we can either throw up our hands and resign ourselves to diminishing living standards, or we can do what America has always done, which is adapt, and pull together, and fight back, and win.
label: true_

sentences: That’s what we have to do.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )And that brings me to the second cornerstone of a strong middle class -- and everybody here knows it -- an education that prepares our children and our workers for the global competition that they’re going to face.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: And if you think education is expensive, wait until you see how much ignorance costs in the 21st century.
label: true_

sentences: (Laughter and applause.
label: true_

sentences: )If we don’t make this investment, we’re going to put our kids, our workers, and our country at a competitive disadvantage for decades.
label: true_

sentences: So we have to begin in the earliest years.
label: true_

sentences: And that’s why I’m going to keep pushing to make high-quality preschool available for every 4-year-old in America.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: Not just because we know it works for our kids, but because it provides a vital support system for working parents.And I’m going to take action in the education area to spur innovation that don’t require Congress.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: )Now, so you’ve got a good job; you get a good education -- those have always been the key stepping stones into the middle class.

sentences: )Good job; good education for your kids; home of your own; secure retirement.Fifth, I'm going to keep focusing on health care -- (applause) -- because middle-class families and small business owners deserve the security of knowing that neither an accident or an illness is going to threaten the dreams that you’ve worked a lifetime to build.As we speak, we're well on our way to fully implementing the Affordable Care Act.

sentences: Now, if you’re one of the 85 percent of Americans who already have health insurance either through the job or Medicare or Medicaid, you don’t have to do anything, but you do have new benefits and better protections than you did before.

sentences: Free checkups, mammograms, discounted medicines if you're on Medicare -- that’s what the Affordable Care Act means.

sentences: There will be a marketplace online, just like you’d buy a flat-screen TV or plane tickets or anything else you're doing online, and you'll be able to buy an insurance package that fits your budget and is right for you.And if you're one of the up to half of all Americans who’ve been sick or have a preexisting condition -- if you look at this auditorium, about half of you probably have a preexisting condition that insurance companies could use to not give you insurance if you lost your job or lost your insurance -- well, this law means that beginning January 1st, insurance companies will finally have to cover you and charge you the same rates as everybody else, even if you have a preexisting condition.

sentences: (Applause.)
label: true_

sentences: That’s what the Affordable Care Act does.

label: true_

sentences: And that means we cannot turn our backs when bad breaks hit any of our fellow citizens.So good jobs; a better bargain for the middle class and the folks who are working to get into the middle class; an economy that grows from the middle out, not the top down -- that's where I will focus my energies.

sentences: (Applause.

label: true_

sentences: )It’s interesting, in the run-up to this speech, a lot of reporters say that, well, Mr. President, these are all good ideas, but some of you’ve said before; some of them sound great, but you can't get those through Congress.

sentences: But they worry they’ll face swift political retaliation for cooperating with me.Now, there are others who will dismiss every idea I put forward either because they’re playing to their most strident supporters, or in some cases because, sincerely, they have a fundamentally different vision for America -- one that says inequality is both inevitable and just; one that says an unfettered free market without any restraints inevitably produces the best outcomes, regardless of the pain and uncertainty imposed on ordinary families; and government is the problem and we should just shrink it as small as we can.In either case, I say to these members of Congress: I’m laying out my ideas to give the middle class a better shot.

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: So it’s not enough for you just to oppose me.

sentences: That’s not a vision we should be passing on to our children.I have now run my last campaign.

label: true_

sentences: I care about one thing and one thing only, and that’s how to use every minute -- (applause) -- the only thing I care about is how to use every minute of the remaining 1,276 days of my term -- (laughter) -- to make this country work for working Americans again.

sentences: And it may seem hard today, but if we’re willing to take a few bold steps -- if Washington will just shake off its complacency and set aside the kind of slash-and-burn partisanship that we’ve just seen for way too long -- if we just make some common-sense decisions, our economy will be stronger a year from now.

label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )If we focus on what matters, then more Americans will know the pride of that first paycheck.

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )And in the end, isn't that what makes us special?

sentences: That’s what we're fighting for.So, yes, Congress is tough right now, but that’s not going to stop me.

sentences: But we're going to focus on this thing that matters.One of America’s greatest writers, Carl Sandburg, born right here in Galesburg over a century ago -- (applause) -- he saw the railroads bring the world to the prairie, and then the prairie sent out its bounty to the world.
